text: hello this is Rita from the publication
team at MIT open
courseware I would like to show you a
few sections from a course called
documentary photography and
photojournalism still images of a world
in motion the course is taught by
Professor Bey Cen a senior
Communications officer for University
science at Harvard University and a
Communications advisor at Harvard stem
cell Institute he shared the 1984 pullit
surprise for General local reporting
while working as a reporter editor and
columnist at Newsday he has won many
national and local journalism Awards
during a 23-year career at the
Washington Post and
Newsday I chose to share this course
with you because I think this type of
Photography reveals Beautiful Stories in
a powerful and unique way
students in this course learn to see the
world around them in a new way and
produce a documentary project the class
emphasizes thinking about why people
take photographs what photographs mean
to us and how one can tell stories
through
photographs in the image gallery you
will see some of the documentaries that
the students have developed let's take a
look at the last sock lonely
laundromat laundromats tend to be filled
with a wide variety of people but much
like oil and water you can put different
people together in a laundromat but they
want mix the people in laundromats are
engaging in a very private act in a very
public place and they do everything
possible to compensate for that the
people at the L sock laundromat act much
like planets orbiting around each other
but never
meeting let's now take a look at the A
Day in the Life Judy Freeman image
gallery
page Boston Latin School is not your
average high school the school was
founded in 1635 as the first school in
colonial America its reputation and
history is as prolific as its list of
alumni which includes five signers of
the Declaration of Independence the
school is now home to over 2500 students
this documentary takes you through a day
in the life of Boston Latin history
teacher Judy Freeman I enjoyed working
on this course and I hope you will enjoy
exploring it you can explore more
courses like this one at
ocw.mit.edu or get email updates from
ocw by subscribing to a monthly
newsletter we hope you you will keep us
going and growing by making a donation
at
ocw.mit.edu donate
